key_points: The Interior Department's Office of Inspector General will investigate the department's role before and during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
The investigation will be coordinated with parallel probes by the inspectors general of the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, and Department of Justice.
The violence on Jan. 6 resulted in at least five deaths and raised concerns about security for the upcoming presidential inauguration.
The Interior Department includes the National Park Service and U.S. Park Police, both of which have law enforcement responsibilities.
Representatives from the Park Police and National Park Service have not commented on the investigation.
Kenneth Spencer, chairman of the US Park Police Fraternal Order of Police, criticized the Park Police's preparation for potential unrest.
Spencer highlighted issues such as outdated equipment, heavy turnover, and difficulty retaining officers.
Speaker Nancy Pelosi asked retired Army lieutenant general Russell Honoré to lead a review of Capitol security infrastructure.
Congressional committees will conduct oversight related to the attacks and security posture.
There is interest in Congress for a 9/11-type commission to assess the events surrounding January 6.
spokespersons: Kenneth Spencer (Chairman, US Park Police Fraternal Order of Police)
Nancy Pelosi (Speaker, United States House of Representatives)
